awd_titl_txt: Conference Proposal: Diversifying the 2022 AOS-BC Conference in San Juan, Puerto Rico
awd_abstract_narration:
Like most other areas of science, ornithology (the study of birds) lacks the diversity that is critical to a healthy, vibrant, and productive field of research. Much-needed efforts to broaden participation in the sciences have accelerated in recent years, particularly with respect to making science more welcoming and inclusive to individuals from groups that historically have been marginalized or excluded. Moreover, the popularity of recreational birding and the increasing number of volunteers participating in bird-themed citizen science projects has put ornithology in the spotlight with regard to calls for diversity and inclusion in the sciences. The joint 2022 conference of the American Ornithological Society (AOS) and BirdsCaribbean (BC) will be a powerful platform for activities to broaden participation in the field of ornithology. Being the first in-person meeting for either society in over two years, and being held in Puerto Rico, AOS & BC 2022 will be very well attended and will provide unusually strong training and outreach opportunities. By bringing together so many individuals with such diverse perspectives, the conference is certain to push ornithology in new directions.

This project will have direct impacts on diversity and inclusion within the discipline of ornithology. First, Diversity and Inclusion Travel Grants, and Caregiver Grants, will ensure a diverse pool of attendees. This diversity will be further enhanced by funds to support attendance by local Puerto Ricans. All of these attendees will participate in the broader scientific sessions, training workshops, and mentoring/networking events. Additionally, this project will support three workshops that will directly address broadening participation in ornithology. Together, these efforts at AOS & BC 2022 directly lead to a broader and more inclusive discipline, and will provide a solid basis for future efforts aimed at making ornithology and other STEM disciplines more diverse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Like most other STEM fields, ornithology lacks the diversity that is critical to a healthy, vibrant, and productive field of research. Much-needed efforts to broaden participation in the sciences have accelerated in recent years, particularly with respect to making science more welcoming and inclusive to individuals from groups that historically have been marginalized or excluded. Similarly, high profile educational and outreach events have the goal of making recreational bird-watching more broadly inclusive. Indeed, the popularity of recreational birding has put ornithology in the spotlight with regard to calls for diversity and inclusion in the sciences. 

 

The joint 2022 conference of the American Ornithological Society (AOS) and BirdsCaribbean (BC) provided a powerful platform for activities that will broaden participation in the field of ornithology. Being the first in-person meeting for either society in over two years, and being held in Puerto Rico, AOS & BC 2022 provided unusually strong training and outreach opportunities. The major goals of this award were aimed at capitalizing on these opportunities. Specifically, this award supported three principal activities at AOS & BC 2022 aimed at diversifying participation in professional and semi-professional ornithology.

 

First, this award provided funds to support travel and participation that directly diversified the attendees pool. A Diversity and Inclusion (D&I) Travel Grant program, aimed specifically at alleviating the financial constraints that often create significant barriers to participation by traditionally marginalized groups. This program provided travel support for students and early professionals that self-identify with a historically marginalized group or who are actively contributing to DEI efforts. Similarly, Caregiver Grants helped support child- or elder-care for conference attendees. These were intended to allow an individual to accompany the registrant to attend to childcare, or to cover expenses for child/elder care to be provided in the meeting attendees absence ? whether at their home or at the meeting location. 

 

Second, this award supported participation by local Puerto Ricans. Holding a major ornithological conference in Puerto Rico offered a unique opportunity to provide training, mentoring, and capacity building opportunities for locals who may have limited opportunities to travel to a conference on the mainland. This includes graduate students and early professionals already embarking on a career in science, but also others at earlier stages (e.g., undergraduates and even high school students) who may not yet realize that a career in STEM is a possibility. This award was used to bring local Puerto Ricans to the conference by providing funds to cover registration and some regional travel funds. Importantly, the first day of the conference was designated as ?Puerto Rico Day? and highlighted avian research and conservation efforts on the island. 

 

Third, this award supported several events at the AOS & BC 2022 conference that were aimed at highlighting and promoting diversity in ornithology. This included two roundtables and a workshop. One roundtable (?Decolonizing Bird Conservation), panelists discussed what led them to engage in this work, and what they are doing to close the racial gaps in STEAM, so that other organizations and individuals can apply these methods to their own work. They also highlighted the disparities in STEAM programs whose work aligns closely with bird conservation. The second roundtable (?Practical steps and tips for students interested in attending graduate school in the US and Canada?) provided information about identifying, applying, and succeeding in graduate school in the US and Canada, especially for students from Latin America and the Caribbean. Finally, the workshop (?Empowering Diversity in Ornithology?) explored diversity in ornithology from recruitment to retention, sharing successful methods for guiding underrepresented youth to careers in ornithology and other STEM fields.
